Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.raw_text: Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707–08 (1973) (abolishing common-law distinctions between invitees and licensees and imposing a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors)
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, a property owner or person in control of premises abutting a public way owes a duty to exercise reasonable care so as not to cause or allow foreseeable and unreasonable risks of harm to persons lawfully using the public way.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.support_reasoning: The quoted passage from Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurring opinion focused on abolishing the licensee/invitee distinction and discussing the treatment of trespassers. It concerns the duty owed by occupiers to persons on their premises, not the duty of owners of premises abutting a public way to users of that way. The text provided does not address abutting‑way liability or articulate any rule about reasonable care toward persons lawfully using a public way, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct."

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.raw_text: Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739, 743–44 (1995) (landowner must act reasonably to prevent foreseeable harm to others)
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, a property owner or person in control of premises abutting a public way owes a duty to exercise reasonable care so as not to cause or allow foreseeable and unreasonable risks of harm to persons lawfully using the public way.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The opinion acknowledges a general duty of landowners to exercise reasonable care and not injure travelers on adjacent highways, but its holding is that an abutting owner generally has no duty regarding the safety of users of a public way it does not control, beyond using its own land with reasonable care. The court explicitly rejects imposing a duty on the landowner to provide safe passage across the public way or to control conditions on the State highway. Thus, the case limits, rather than affirms, the broad duty described in the proposition.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors… Although a landowner or possessor typically is not held to any duty with respect to public highways adjacent to or crossing his land, he must exercise reasonable care in the use of his land so as not to injure a traveler on the highway. … The mere fact that Westwood’s facilities used land on both sides of Route 1A… does not necessarily impose on it the broad duty to provide safe passage over the State highway… This we decline to do.”

Michalski v. Hinz, 469 Mass. 503, 507\u2.raw_text: Michalski v. Hinz, 469 Mass. 503, 507–09 (2014) (recognizing landowner duty to address conditions posing reasonably foreseeable risks)
Michalski v. Hinz, 469 Mass. 503, 507\u2.proposition: This duty extends to hazardous conditions on the premises, including trees or branches that, by reason of their condition and proximity, pose a foreseeable risk of falling into an adjacent public way and injuring passersby.
Michalski v. Hinz, 469 Mass. 503, 507\u2.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns criminal sentencing, correction of an illegal sentence, GPS monitoring, and double jeopardy principles. It does not address premises liability, landowner duties, or hazardous conditions such as trees or branches affecting an adjacent public way. Accordingly, it cannot support the proposition about a landowner’s duty regarding hazardous tree conditions near public ways.
Michalski v. Hinz, 469 Mass. 503, 507\u2.relevant_excerpt: We begin by noting that the defendant’s initial sentence was, in fact, illegal for its failure to include GPS monitoring. … Given this premise, we consider whether the sentencing judge had the authority to correct the defendant’s illegal sentence, then examine whether he was time barred from doing so under the principles of double jeopardy.

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.proposition: A landowner is required to act with the care of a reasonably prudent person in like circumstances to inspect for, discover, and remedy dangerous conditions of which the landowner knows or in the exercise of reasonable care should know.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely restates the general Massachusetts rule that a landowner owes lawful entrants a common-law duty of reasonable care, which includes maintaining the premises in a reasonably safe condition and warning of unreasonable dangers the landowner knows or should know about. That is effectively the same as requiring a reasonably prudent person to inspect for, discover, and remedy dangerous conditions of which the landowner knows or, in the exercise of reasonable care, should know. The case then applies and elaborates on that duty in the open-and-obvious-danger context.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … It also includes an obligation ‘to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.’”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..raw_text: Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 372–73 (2010) (landowner liability where failure to use reasonable care to maintain property causes injury)
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: A landowner is required to act with the care of a reasonably prudent person in like circumstances to inspect for, discover, and remedy dangerous conditions of which the landowner knows or in the exercise of reasonable care should know.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The court expressly rejects the natural/unnatural accumulation limitation and holds that snow-and-ice hazards are governed by the same general premises liability rule as all other hazards. It states that where a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition, including snow and ice, the owner has a duty to act as a reasonable person under all the circumstances to protect lawful visitors, which necessarily includes reasonable inspection, discovery, and remediation of such conditions.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973) (notice inferred from nature and duration of defect)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Where a hazardous condition, including a dangerous tree or branch, is open, obvious, longstanding, or the subject of specific complaints, a landowner is charged with actual or constructive notice of the condition and must take reasonable steps to inspect and correct the hazard.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The case concerns a slip-and-fall on a foreign substance on stairs in a subway station and addresses when circumstantial evidence permits an inference that the defendant had actual or constructive notice of that substance. It does not involve trees, branches, or comparable fixed hazardous conditions, and it ultimately holds that the evidence was insufficient to infer the condition existed long enough to charge the defendant with notice. Thus, while it discusses constructive notice generally, it does not affirm the broader proposition that open, obvious, longstanding hazards or prior complaints charge a landowner with notice; it is a narrow timing/foreign-substance case and actually denies recovery.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The issue presented is whether the evidence is sufficient to permit a jury to infer that the substance had been on the step long enough so that in the exercise of reasonable care the defendant should have discovered and removed it… The length of time allowed to a defendant is governed by the circumstances of each case… In summary, recovery has been denied to the plaintiff in the great majority of cases where he has attempted to establish the time element by circumstantial evidence consisting for the most part of a description of the foreign substance.”

Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 265 (1961)
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.proposition: Where a hazardous condition, including a dangerous tree or branch, is open, obvious, longstanding, or the subject of specific complaints, a landowner is charged with actual or constructive notice of the condition and must take reasonable steps to inspect and correct the hazard.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.support_reasoning: The case deals with a transient spill in a store and the standards for proving a storeowner’s notice of that condition; it does not involve a hazardous tree or branch, or any discussion of a condition being open, obvious, longstanding, or the subject of prior complaints. Instead, the court holds that, absent proof the store caused the spill or that it existed long enough to be discoverable through reasonable care, the defendant had no actual or constructive notice and is not liable. This is a more restrictive view of constructive notice than the broad proposition stated.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.relevant_excerpt: “Where, without action for which he is responsible, a dangerous condition arises, the law allows him reasonable opportunity to become informed of the danger and to take measures to remedy it. He is not liable, in such a case, unless he is negligent in failing to inform himself and to take appropriate action… In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers.”

Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermkts., Inc.,.raw_text: Thurlow v. Shaw’s Supermkts., Inc., 49 Mass. App. Ct. 175, 177–78 (2000)
Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermkts., Inc.,.proposition: Even absent direct complaints, the cracked, drooping, and obviously compromised condition of the Defective Branch over a period of time gave rise to constructive notice: a reasonable landowner in Defendant’s position would have recognized the risk and taken remedial action.
Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermkts., Inc.,.support_reasoning: The case directly applies constructive notice principles to a hazard that developed over time from an ongoing, observable condition (melting/spilled ice from a display case), even without prior complaints. The court approved the trial judge’s inference that, given the time elapsed, the obvious nature of the melting, and employee proximity, the store “reasonably should have been aware” of the condition and taken action. This aligns with the proposition that an obviously compromised condition over a period of time can give rise to constructive notice to a reasonable landowner.
Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermkts., Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “Although sweeps of the entire store floor were performed on a regular basis, the judge found that the last sweep of the floor was at 10 p.m., or about one and three-quarters hours before the accident took place. Based upon that time frame, the obvious nature of the melting, and the fact that at least one store employee was near, the judge concluded that the defendant had constructive notice of the hazard… we are not prepared to say that the judge’s finding that ‘someone at Shaw’s reasonably should have been aware of this amount of water on the floor in front of the fish display case [for almost two hours]’ is plainly wrong.”

Fiorentino v. Mason, 233 Mass. 451, 452\.raw_text: Fiorentino v. Mason, 233 Mass. 451, 452–53 (1919) (liability where landowner’s failure to remove dangerous condition caused foreseeable harm)
Fiorentino v. Mason, 233 Mass. 451, 452\.proposition: Defendant’s inaction in the face of actual and constructive notice of an obvious hazard constitutes a breach of the duty of care imposed by Massachusetts law.
Fiorentino v. Mason, 233 Mass. 451, 452\.support_reasoning: The case is about the scope of a landlord’s contractual duty to repair in a tenancy at will and when that duty sounds in contract versus tort; it does not stand for a general rule that inaction in the face of actual or constructive notice of an obvious hazard is a breach of a Massachusetts duty of care. In fact, the court holds that, absent a specific, broader agreement (a “third class” contract retaining control and imposing a duty to inspect), the landlord is not liable in tort merely for failing to repair even known defects. Thus, the opinion undercuts, rather than supports, the broad negligence proposition asserted.
Fiorentino v. Mason, 233 Mass. 451, 452\.relevant_excerpt: “It is not made out by a simple agreement that the landlord will keep the premises in repair. That *454 means no more than that he will keep them in repair on notice from the tenant. Such an agreement is of the second class. An agreement of the third class goes much further… Under such an agreement liability devolves upon the landlord for any failure reasonably to discover and remedy a defect or want of repair whereby injury ensues…”

Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.raw_text: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105–07 (1978) (defendant liable where negligent failure to address foreseeable danger leads to injury)
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.proposition: The ordinary summer thunderstorm that occurred on July 15, 2023, was a foreseeable weather event in Massachusetts and was precisely the type of condition that made a visibly cracked and drooping branch especially likely to fail.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns premises liability for an unsecured forklift and the foreseeability of misuse by intoxicated seamen; it does not address weather, storms, trees, or falling branches. While it discusses foreseeability generally, it provides no authority about whether a summer thunderstorm in Massachusetts is a foreseeable event or about vegetation-related risks in such weather. Using this case to support a specific proposition about foreseeability of a thunderstorm and tree-branch failure mischaracterizes its holding and context.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.relevant_excerpt: “Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable. The authority had specific procedures for securing the forklifts… It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition on premises which were solely under the authority’s control, would be operated by unauthorized persons… It was also reasonably foreseeable… that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area…”

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.raw_text: Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320–21 (2002) (foreseeability and proximate cause)
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: The harm suffered by Plaintiff—being struck and injured by a falling tree branch while walking on the adjacent public sidewalk—was a reasonably foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s failure to act, and there were no superseding or intervening causes that would break the chain of causation.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The case discusses foreseeability and proximate cause, but it holds that the harm was *not* a reasonably foreseeable consequence of the defendant’s conduct and that an intervening act (the INS’s later decision to release MacNeil) was a superseding cause breaking the chain of causation. The proposition asserts the opposite—that the harm was reasonably foreseeable and that there were no superseding or intervening causes. Thus, Kent v. Commonwealth is contrary authority, not supporting authority, for that proposition.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct… If a series of events occur between the negligent conduct and the ultimate harm, the court must determine whether those intervening events have broken the chain of factual causation or, if not, have otherwise extinguished the element of proximate cause and become a superseding cause of the harm.… [T]he INS action constituted a superseding cause of the harm that followed.”

Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 58–61 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.proposition: Defendant’s negligence need not be the sole cause of Plaintiff’s injuries; it is sufficient that Defendant’s conduct was a substantial contributing factor in bringing about Plaintiff’s injuries.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: This excerpt is a dissent focused entirely on whether the plaintiff proved proximate cause on the facts; it does not discuss or adopt any rule about whether a defendant’s negligence must be the sole cause versus a substantial contributing factor. The dissent applies a traditional proximate cause and foreseeability analysis and concludes causation was speculative, but it neither states nor implies the substantial-factor standard described in the proposition. Thus, this citation does not provide authority for the claimed legal principle.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: "In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor."

Haddad v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (No. 1),.raw_text: Haddad v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (No. 1), 455 Mass. 91, 100–01 (2009) (recognizing recovery for pain and suffering and other noneconomic damages)
Haddad v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (No. 1),.proposition: Plaintiff has suffered and will continue to suffer physical pain and suffering, mental anguish, emotional distress, inconvenience, and loss of enjoyment of life as a result of the injuries caused by Defendant’s negligence.
Haddad v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (No. 1),.support_reasoning: The opinion is an employment discrimination case focused on back pay, front pay, and punitive damages under Massachusetts antidiscrimination law. While it notes an award of emotional distress damages as part of compensatory damages, it does not discuss or recognize the broader tort-negligence concept that a plaintiff who suffers physical pain, mental anguish, emotional distress, inconvenience, and loss of enjoyment of life from a defendant’s negligence may recover such noneconomic damages. Thus it does not meaningfully support the specific negligence-based damages proposition cited.
Haddad v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (No. 1),.relevant_excerpt: "The jury awarded $17,700 in special damages, $125,000 in emotional distress damages, back pay of $95,000, and front pay of $733,307. See Stonehill College v. Massachusetts Comm’n Against Discrimination, 441 Mass. 549, 567-568, cert. denied sub nom. Wilfert Bros. Realty Co. v. Massachusetts Comm’n Against Discrimination, 543 U.S. 979 (2004) (to effectuate remedial purpose of statute, compensatory damages include those which are ‘natural and probable consequences’ of discriminatory act)."

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, which confers original jurisdiction on the Superior Court over civil actions in which the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1 and \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in Berkshire County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 and § 3 because the cause of action arose in Berkshire County, the Defendant resides in Berkshire County, and the subject premises are located at 123 Maple Street in Pittsfield, Berkshire County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60F (addressing proo.raw_text: G.L. c. 231, § 60F (addressing proof of medical expenses as evidence of fair and reasonable charge)
G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60F (addressing proo.proposition: Plaintiff incurred reasonable and necessary medical expenses of approximately $2,500 for evaluation and treatment of her injuries, and such expenses were the natural and probable consequence of the injuries caused by Defendant’s negligence.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, Plaintiff is entitled to statutory prejudgment interest on any judgment for personal injuries from the date of commencement of this action.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.proposition: Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable as of right pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 38 and applicable Massachusetts law.
